we show you that draft in slack so slack is a communication and collaboration platform so we want to take advantage of

this draft to a select Channel your teammates can review make sure all the information is correct before you actually create the case with support
case updates and notifications are also posted to channels and you can take action from buttons on these slack
messages I can view the full case details and decide to reopen a certain case and that correspondence is added to
the thread where the original message was posted in this fashion multiple teammates not just the Case Creator can
collaborate on and update a case and one of the big differentiators from our customers so far has been the live
chat functionality in slack when you request a live chat in slack we create a dedicated channel for that chat where
you can communicate with the support engineer directly from slack the agent's messages in the chat are also posted to
this Channel and this is just a standard slack Channel otherwise you can invite as many teammates as you want to this
channel so multiple people can participate in a live chat which is something you cannot do from the console
and it's not all strictly support case management and slack you can also search for cases in slack to maybe get your
list of open cases in the past month to share to your Channel and you can also request service quota
increases directly from slack as well so what are the benefits that we're trying to provide to customers who
decide to adopt this product well first of all it's a unified interface where you can collaborate with support and
with your teammates we know that there is already communication today that happens in slack when a particular case
is being raised or debugged with support and now you don't have to switch products and go to the console to get updates or add a correspondence to a
case you do it in slack where you're already communicating about this case with your team and you don't have to worry about one or
a couple of people having to really own the case and copy updates to slack Channels with more team members team members can be in those channels and be
kept up to date in real time as case updates come in and lastly we're hopeful that this
increased transparency and collaboration leads to root causes being identified faster because there's not a bunch of
games of telephone going on at once and everyone's collaborating within the same platform
so now that you have that introduction I want to talk about how this actually works now this section is not intended
to be an architectural model it's more of an interaction model and here's a bird's eye view of what a
case interaction model looks like in the support app you actually have two main personas that are involved you the
customer and your users in slack and then AWS support and the engineer working a particular case
regardless of which Persona is interacting with your case or how they are interacting with it updates are
still persisted to that case for an account so I want to walk through each of the flows you see here on the screen one by
one I'm going to start with the AWS support side of things their workflow actually has not changed a single agent is still
assigned to your case and they make their updates in their console and those updates are posted to the support case
for a particular account again nothing has changed but they're a key persona for our product and I wanted
to touch on their experience and flipping over to the primary user Persona there is also workflow that
remains unchanged here support center is not going anywhere you can still log into your account and create and manage
cases with support from the AWS console in a similar fashion you can continue to use the support API to create and manage
cases for an account basically the presence of the support app in slack does not mean your previous ways of
managing cases are now invalid having said that we do hope that most existing support customers who use slack
migrate their case management process into this part of the interaction model users in a select channel can all
perform actions on a case that are then persisted to the corresponding AWS account we've seen feedback from early
adopters about how slack has positively impacted their workflows and we want everyone else to receive these benefits
as well and you may notice how they're actually multiple arrows going from slack to the AWS account icon
and this is because a single select channel can actually reference multiple AWS accounts so from a single Channel
users can create a case for account a or account B they can search for cases in account a or account B they can receive
case updates for account a or account B and so on this use case has been noted as one of the big benefits of the
support app in slot compared to existing mechanisms you could even have a single slack channel that handles cases for
most or all of your AWS accounts and there's one more thing I want to mention about the support app

notifications are posted to your slack Channel for example you could say that for a particular account you want every new
case regardless of whether it's created in the console or in slack to get posted to your select Channel as a notification
and so that notification comes into the slack Channel your channel members May interact with that notification and

well there's no link between a slack user and that AWS account how do we determine what permissions the users in
a channel should have for an AWS account well we actually use an IAM role this
role sets the account permissions for all users in a particular slack channel so when those Channel users go to take
action on cases in slack the I am role is used to determine what permissions the users have on cases so our
interaction model really looks a bit more like this and I know I am policies and roles and
such may be familiar to a lot of you but I did want to quickly walk through what this looks like just in case you need to
have an IM policy to attach to an IM role so you can either create your own policy first in the console and
fine-tune the permissions or you can actually use one of our two manage policies when you go to create the role so regarding managed policies in
particular we have one that is for full access so users can create cases resolve
cases add Communications and so on and we have another for read-only Access where users can see case and
communication details but can't actually perform any updates on the case the advantage to manage policies which
is again something some of you may be familiar with is that it is an AWS own policy so you don't have to worry about
getting every permission correct and if we ever have to update it in the future we'll do it for you to fit that full
access or read-only use case once you have created your own policy or
decided you want to use one of our manage policies you create an IM role in the console you'll select AWS Service as The Trusted
entity type and then find AWS Support app in the drop down and on the next screen you'll search for
